citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The written program of veterinary care, contingency plan, acquisition and disposition documents were not accessible by
the facility representative and available for review at time of inspection. Review of records required by the Animal Welfare
Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspectors to determine compliance and to ensure the health and
well-being of the animals. The licensee must, during business hours, allow APHIS officials to examine records required to
be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations.
Correct by 20 September 2024.

There was a moderate accumulation of rodent feces in the office/medical supply room including on cabinet shelves,
underneath a sink, and along areas of the floor along the walls and corners. Additionally in the main barn, there were
accumulations of rodent feces on a pallet next to the hay supply and bags of feed. The licensee indicated the current
program in place to address rodents include the use of traps and barn cats. Pests and vermin may contaminate food as
well as harbor and spread diseases. A safe and effective pest control program must be established and maintained to
protect the health and well-being of the animals.
Correct by 27 September 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
TYLER FIELDS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
The written program of veterinary care, contingency plan, acquisition and disposition documents were not accessible by 
the facility representative and available for review at time of inspection. Review of records required by the Animal Welfare 
Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspectors to determine compliance and to ensure the health and 
well-being of the animals. The licensee must, during business hours, allow APHIS officials to examine records required to 
be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations. 
 
Correct by 20 September 2024. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
There was a moderate accumulation of rodent feces in the office/medical supply room including on cabinet shelves, 
underneath a sink, and along areas of the floor along the walls and corners. Additionally in the main barn, there were 
accumulations of rodent feces on a pallet next to the hay supply and bags of feed. The licensee indicated the current 
program in place to address rodents include the use of traps and barn cats. Pests and vermin may contaminate food as 
well as harbor and spread diseases. A safe and effective pest control program must be established and maintained to 
protect the health and well-being of the animals. 
 
Correct by 27 September 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
TYLER FIELDS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
